Potential expulsions for SUNY and CUNY students convicted of hate crimes, amidst surge in antisemitic incidents

by Ashley Cusicanqui

Thu, November 9th 2023, 10:44 PM UTC
legislation introduced to combat antisemitism on SUNY and CUNY campuses

Expulsions could be coming to SUNY and CUNY students who are convicted of a hate crime.

NY Senator (R) Saratoga Springs Jim Tedisco announced legislation today saying people do have the right for freedom of speech but they do not have a right to be anti-Semitic or racist with a state education paid for by the taxpayers.

The Anti-Defamation League reported a nearly 400% increase in antisemitic incidents in the U.S. following the Israel-Hamas war with 54 antisemitic incidents on college campuses.

Since Governor Hochul has ordered a probe for incidents of antisemitism in CUNY schools.

Tedisco's bill would add a penalty to New York State's Hate Crimes Law.

"I don't think we should allow taxpayers' dollars to be used when young people use this type of rhetoric, use this type of extremism, call for this type of violence to involve their selves in terrorism," Senator Tedisco said. "They shouldn't be allowed to be on campus, use taxpayers' dollars to get their education, they'll have to go elsewhere if they do that."

Meanwhile, in the Assembly, lawmakers agree more needs to be done to ensure the safety of students and educators.

The proposal, “Dismantling Student Antisemitism Act” (DSA Act), would require all who attend a New York college to go to seminars on antisemitism awareness and Jewish history.

It would also require an expert in the area of antisemitism awareness, prevention and Jewish history to conduct the seminars.

State aid penalties are also included if a school fails to comply.

"It seems amazing to me that some of the greatest offenders particularly when it comes to the antisemitic activities are professors administrators and students, the ones that are supposedly so open-minded," said NY Assemblyman Minority Leader (R) Will Barclay. "That they are the ones that have to teach everybody else how to be sensitive to it but then we have these outrageous acts of antisemitism going on."

One student has been arrested for promoting violence against the Jewish Community at Cornell University.
